title: Linked Open Data Session

author: Daniel Vila Suero, Universidad Politécnica de Madrid

segmentation: I am going to talk about naming and labeling in the multilingual web of data.
A.

This is based on our work that we presented in the Dublin Core Conference two years ago, one year and something to go in, and it was called style guidelines for naming and labeling ontologies, but it's actually very preliminary work and where we analyze the state of the art on guidelines for actually naming and labeling ontologies or resources or vocabularies naming is to assign the UI's for the things that you're going to publish.
And by labeling we understand the description that we provide for this for these resources.
But actually I will not focus on the on this preliminary guidelines that we provided, but I will.
I would rather focus on on some practical examples of the usage of these vocabularies.

We used as experience for providing these guidelines and this is the work that we did supplying these if lava calories to the data when data set which is the National Library of Spain, RDF data set and also the translation into Spanish of the vocabularies.
So I will start with naming.
For naming, we find several guidelines, especially in the English.
In the English speaking world, like from the Cabinet Office in the UK.
Also, the color your eyes from Tim Berners Lee and also another note from the technical architectural group in the WCC.
So mainly what they say is don't put too much semantics.
Please use sort your eyes, use lower case, choose case policy, etc.
But what we found is there were no.
No specific guidelines for for a multi lingual scenario.
For our non speaking non English speaking country so.
What we device there was a set of very very preliminary guidelines and we said something very polemic in that in that paper, and as you have seen, this money, that's not many people agree with that.
And we said that in a multilingual international scenario, when you have several languages, please use opaque.
You arise and that's what they did for IFLA in this case.
And this is one of the use cases that we show in that paper.
And we also said if you are a half a.
A language other than English, and you want to use meaningful your eyes.
Please put all the language, the diacritics and so on.
So use IR eyes, not your eyes, and so on.
But I don't want to focus on these guidelines.

I want to show you today it's a some experiences that I had after writing the paper, so I started to use these vocabularies which used to pay your eyes in the data center project and we found several issues and we found also we received some negative feedback, specially by using open your eyes.
So this is an example.
Some reviewer told us it is a pity that local names of IFLA.
Properties are cryptic codes, but the authors of these papers are not to blame about that.
OK, at the beginning I thought yes, hey, I'm so happy they review is done.
Blame us, but I actually thought maybe it's our fault because there are technologies that actually can leverage their DFS labels provided by IFLA.
So this in this in this point that the problem was the technology that we were using.
Now the standards know the best practices and so on.
So.

As an example of other technology that actually uses our DFS labels before putting the UI or the compact UI in the in the display in the display in the user interface, is this link data is API specification where you can actually configure the display of labels and you can actually leverage the DFS.
Labels are DFS, description and so on.
So we started using this and with this we could have a more or less localized interface in Spanish.
But we also found some deficiencies in these technologies.
So my main point here is that maybe we have the mechanisms, but we really need to have the appropriate appropriate tooling for actually leveraging multilingual web of data applications.
So also some personal experiences actually building a some prototypes on applications on this on this data, not only out of the box solutions as the ones I have shown you.
So.
How many times this is for only for developers, developers.
Maybe it's too technical, but how many times you write on your eye when you are writing a link data application, maybe just once as you do with file locations in your local server?
I mean you can use constants and so on, so maybe it's not that bad to have opaque UI.
OK, and for issuing queries to sparkle endpoints with opaque your eyes, it's actually very, very painful because you don't know the vocabulary and so on.
But maybe it's about tooling again and also what is better to use this kind of your eyes that are very descriptive but you have something like a really long word.
Really long sentence has a statement of responsibility and so on.
Or to use a short UI with an opaque code.
So for labeling I will go very.
First a.
We also found that there were no guidelines in this in this multi lingual scenario.
So we propose some some of these guidelines that maybe we can discuss later on.
And finally I wanted to give an example of this cartographic issue that they mention mentioned by Gordon, and it's actually quite feasible to represent it using lemon.
So what we have there is a sense.
A lexical entry with the masculine form and the feminine form.
OK, thank you.
